results.title: Dark days [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Wide Angle Pictures, Palm Pictures, Picture Farm and Marc Singer
results.brief_description: In “Dark days”, first-time filmmaker Marc Singer has documented the lives of the tunnel-dwellers living in deserted segments of New York’s subway network. Shot in stark black and white and illuminated by a single spotlight, we follow the journey of these dignified and articulate characters from the homeless drudgery of the tunnel to public housing above the ground, which offers some hope for the future. Along the way they strive to overcome drug addiction, rat infestation, and chronic destitution, not to mention tension in their relationships with fellow inhabitants; all while maintaining a strength which shatters society’s myths of homelessness. The tunnel- dwellers acted not only as the subjects for this documentary, but also producers and crewmembers, fighting for their voice to be heard and their story to be told. Featuring a soundtrack by DJ Shadow, “Dark days” is a moving and very human portrayal of life in the bowels of the western world.

results.title: Dark city [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Dark City Productions, Andrew Mason and Alex Proyas
results.brief_description: Emanating from the same Fox studios as ‘The Matrix’, Alex Proyas’ ‘Dark City’ has the same impressive array of special effects and a rather enigmatic plot. The film begins with an amnesiac John Murdoch (Rufus Sewell) awakening in a bathtub, with no recollection of why he’s there and a tiny bloodspot on his forehead. Other people around him seem to know more about John’s memory than he does, including his estranged wife Emma (Jennifer Connelly), mad genius Dr Schreber (Kiefer Sutherland) and sympathetic policeman Frank Bumstead (William Hurt). John’s investigation into regaining his memory is set against a bleak film noir inspired background where the sun never rises, as well as a murder investigation into a series of deaths involving prostitutes (of which Murdoch is a suspect) and a former policeman (Colin Friels) who seems to have gone mad investigating the case. Both John’s investigation into his past and the police investigation into the murders are intricately involved with The Strangers - a band of gothic looking people who have a collective memory and have the ability to alter the physical world via a process called Turning - a capability that John possesses. The Strangers are driven by the need to replicate humans and ensure The Strangers survival, begging the question, what is it that makes us human? Cast also includes Richard O’Brien, Ian Richardson, Mitchell Butel, Frank Gallacher and Melissa George.

results.title: Dark circle
results.creator_credit: Independent Documentary Group, Chris Beaver, Judy Irving and Ruth Landy
results.brief_description: This is a contemporary portrait of the nuclear age told through the lives of those directly affected by it. The film is shot on location at the Rocky Flats Nuclear Weapons Facility near Denver, the Diablo Canyon Nuclear Power Plant in central California, and in the cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. “Dark Circle” interweaves dramatic personal stories with rare, recently declassified footage of the secret world in which the hydrogen bomb is manufactured, tested and sold. Four years in the making, this film reveals the ironic and complex human costs of a nuclear economy even in the absence of a nuclear war.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Independent Documentary Group, Chris Beaver, Judy Irving and Ruth Landy

results.title: Dark angel
results.creator_credit: Spelling Entertainment, Big Ticket Television, Elisa Kohn Taub and Robert Iscove
results.brief_description: In this made-for-television action thriller, a homicide detective who has been transferred from the Baton Rouge police department to New Orleans under mysterious circumstances is linked to a serial killer who preys on adulterous women. His new superiors assign a female detective to investigate him forcing him to confront his past in order to prove himself innocent before more women are killed. Cast includes Eric Roberts, Ashley Crow, Gina Torres, Linden Ashby.

results.title: Dangerous liaisons
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Lorimar Film Entertainment, NFH Films, Norma Heyman, Hank Moonjean and Stephen Frears
results.brief_description: Valmont (John Malkovich) can’t resist. Wealthy, alluring Merteuil (Glenn Close) has challenged him to seduce the beautiful and very proper Madame de Tourvel (Michelle Pfeiffer), a task involving Valmont’s favourite pastimes, love and revenge. What’s more, Merteuil offers herself as the ultimate prize. So let the game begin. The unspoken rules to this contest of sinful pleasures are second-nature to rakish Valmont. Lie, cheat, deceive, debauch, double-cross, betray. But do not fall in love. The story comes from the frequently banned 1782 novel “Les Liaisons Dangereuses” written by Choderlos De Laclos, and was transformed into an international stage success by Christopher Hampton who then fashioned the play into an Oscar winning movie script. The luxurious setting is pre-French Revolution, but the characters could step into the dog-eat-dog nineties without skipping a beat.

results.title: Dancer in the dark
results.creator_credit: Zentropa Entertainment, France 3 Cinema, Arte France, Trust Film Svenska, Vibeke Windelov and Lars Von Trier
results.brief_description: ‘Dancer in the dark’ is simultaneously an ode to the Hollywood musical, an experiment in digital filmmaking, and a wholly unique, landmark film in contemporary cinema. Similar to ‘Breaking the waves’ and ‘The Idiots’, it centres on a martyr-like female character who is put through excruciating sacrifice and suffering. The setting is rural, 1950s America. Selma (played by Icelandic pop star, Bjork), a Czech immigrant, works day and night to save money for an eye operation that will prevent her son from inheriting an eyesight condition that currently plagues her. What Selma lacks in vision, she makes up for in imagination. ‘Dancer in the dark’ is punctuated with extended fantasy musical sequences in which the drabness of the everyday is transformed into something fantastic, joyous, rhythmic and utopian. Though she enjoys the support of friends, including her best friend Kathy (Catherine Deneuve) and neighbour Bill (David Morse), and is active in the local theatre group, things go from bad to worse for Selma. Loss of financial security and crude betrayal leads to murder, death and an overall Herculean sense of tragedy. Von Trier does many fascinating things in this film. Though he partakes in the Dogme tradition - which seeks to strip away the complete artifice of cinema and usher in the ‘real’ through only ‘natural’ means - Von Trier also reworks and questions it. He does so by juxtaposing documentary-style, almost ‘home-video’ footage, with extremely dazzling, technologically sophisticated, emotionally delirious musical numbers. By throwing together opposite cinematic styles, pushing the characters, the story and the audience to absolute limits of emotional intensity and melodrama, Von Trier not only brings out the essence of the musical as a boundless, overwhelming force, but also asks questions about cinema itself and its powers of storytelling in a post-modern, digital age.

results.title: Dance with a stranger
results.creator_credit: First Film Company, Roger Randall-Cutler and Mike Newell
results.brief_description: The story of Ruth Ellis, a woman tortured by her love for a cruel man who demanded and took from her more than she could possibly give. Her only escape was to rid herself of the terrible pain he caused, so she shot him dead in cold blood. She was convicted of murder and became the last woman in England to be hanged. Starring Miranda Richardson, Rupert Everett and Ian Holm.

results.title: Damn Yankees = What Lola wants
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, George Abbott and Stanley Donen
results.brief_description: Joe Boyd (Robert Schafer), an aging business man and avid baseball follower makes a deal with the devilish Applegate (Ray Walston) to relive his youth and regain a position in the Washington Senators. In the process Boyd becomes the young, handsome “Shoeless” Joe Hardy (played by Tab Hunter), a star baseball player that earns his success at the cost of Boyd’s soul. Boyd has a plan however - or so he thinks, a plan which seems destined to fail when Applegate sends in a beautiful decoy (Gwen Verdon) to seduce the baseball player. It all boils down to a tense game against the New York Yankees in which winning the pennant will also win back Joe’s soul. Based on the Broadway play of the same name and written specially for the screen by Richard Adler, who co-authorised all the original songs with Jerry Ross.

results.title: Damage (E)
results.creator_credit: Skerba NEF, Studio Canal+, Channel 4 and Louis Malle
results.brief_description: Jeremy Irons and Juliette Binoche star in this Louis Malle erotic film about dangerous sexual obsession. Irons, a respected MP, becomes attracted and then involved with his son’s fiance Anna. Despite his promising career, his successful marriage to Miranda Richardson and the love he bears for his son, he cannot bear to give Anna up, and they pursue a dangerous affair which ultimately ends in tragedy. Martin, played by Rupert Graves becomes the innocent victim of their deceit. Miranda Richardson gives a strong albeit brief performance, while Leslie Caron makes a cameo appearance as Anna’s mother.

results.title: Daleks: invasion Earth 2150 A.D. [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: Based on a story from the BBC TV serial “Doctor Who”, Dr. Who and his companions arrive on Earth in the year 2150 AD, only to discover that the planet has been invaded and its population enslaved by the dreaded Daleks. The time travellers assist human resistance groups to foil the Daleks’ plan to mine the Earth’s core.

The time travellers assist human resistance groups to foil the Daleks’ plan to mine the Earth’s core.
